conclusion: Understanding basic principles of shadow formation related to light source position.
Light source is positioned above the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the floor.
Shadows A, B, C, and D are formed due to objects blocking light from reaching certain areas on the floor.
If the light source moves downward, it becomes closer to the floor and objects.
As the light source gets closer, shadows will likely grow larger because light rays have less distance to travel before hitting the floor.
Shadow A will be more pronounced (larger and darker) with the light source closer.
Shadow B will get larger and potentially more distorted due to proximity of the light source.
Shadow C will cast a larger shadow as the light source is closer.
Shadow D will cast a larger shadow since the light source is closer.
Positions of shadows relative to objects should remain similar as the light source moves downward.
Shadows will appear larger due to increased angle between light source and objects.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will become larger; positions will generally stay the same; overall darkness might slightly decrease.
Analysis assumes light source remains a point light and does not become diffuse.
